p: Another explanation is that MAP is not an appropriate metric for measuring plant-available water, and while Δ leaf is still a measure of water use efficiency and this value is dynamic over conditions, snowmelt volumes and/or soil water—as driven by soil porosity and other factors—are better indicators of plant-available water. Further investigations using these variables will better constrain which water-related variables affect Δ leaf values of leaf tissues. The weak R 2 value between Δ leaf of T. occidentalis and MAP (0.0138) means that Δ leaf of T. occidentalis cannot be used to reconstruct paleo-MAP using the relationship determined by Diefendorf et al. (2010). Additional single-species experiments, particularly within angiosperms, should be conducted to look for correlations between Δ leaf and MAP to test whether the lack of relationship is due to a difference inherent to gymnosperms.
